description: Two-panel diagram illustrating Minkowski operations on convex sets. Left: Minkowski sum S1+S2 = {x1+x2 | x1∈S1, x2∈S2}, visualized by 'sweeping' S2 around S1. Right: Minkowski difference/erosion S1⊖S2 = {x | x+S2 ⊆ S1}, visualized as the set of translations where S2 still fits inside S1.

Animation showing vector space axioms are universal across different worlds. Three panels evolving in sync: R² vectors, polynomials a+bx, and functions a*sin(t)+b*cos(t). Same coefficients a(t), b(t) drive all three simultaneously. Proves vector spaces are not defined by geometry—they are defined by addition, scalar multiplication, and axioms.

Animation distinguishing subspace from affine set. Blue arrow: vector in subspace (line through origin). Red arrow: same vector plus fixed offset → affine set. Both move identically but one always passes through 0, the other never does. Clarifies: Ax=0 is a subspace, Ax=b is affine (unless b=0).

Animation of span and generating sets with redundancy. v1, v2 (dashed arrows): generators. v3 (dotted): redundant. Red arrow: all linear combinations αv1+βv2 reach everything v3 ever could. Locks in: span = all linear combinations, redundancy = vectors adding no new reach, basis = minimal spanning set.

Animation of ℓ1 epigraph via dual ℓ∞. Left: diamond ||x||_1 ≤ γ. Red arrow u* = sign(x) always satisfies ||u*||_∞ ≤ 1. Shows identity: sup over ||u||_∞ ≤ 1 of u^T x = ||x||_1. Right: epigraph view t ≥ ||x||_1. u* snaps when x crosses an axis (face-switching).

Animation of ℓ∞ epigraph via dual ℓ1. Left: square ||x||_∞ ≤ γ. Red arrow u* is one-hot vector (all mass on coordinate with largest |x_i|), satisfying ||u*||_1 = 1. Shows identity: sup over ||u||_1 ≤ 1 of u^T x = ||x||_∞. u* jumps when max-absolute coordinate switches.

Animation of dual norm geometry. Shows the dual norm ||u||* = max_{||x||≤1} u^T x as the 'shadow' of u on the unit ball. The supporting hyperplane at the optimal x visually demonstrates the duality relationship. For each u, the animation highlights the maximizing x on the boundary of the unit ball where u^T x is largest.

Animation demonstrating the polar/dual relationship between ℓ1 and ℓ∞ norms. Shows how the unit ball of one norm becomes the polar set of the other. The diamond (ℓ1 ball) and square (ℓ∞ ball) swap roles when taking polars: (ℓ1)° = ℓ∞ ball and (ℓ∞)° = ℓ1 ball. This is the geometric foundation of the duality (ℓ1)* = ℓ∞.

Three-panel animation of supporting hyperplanes sliding over ℓ₁/ℓ∞ balls. Panel 1 (diamond): supporting line is u^T x = sup_{||x||₁≤1} u^T x = ||u||_∞. Panel 2 (square): supporting line is u^T x = sup_{||x||_∞≤1} u^T x = ||u||₁. Panel 3 overlays both: you literally see two different 'shadow lengths' for the same direction u, depending on whether the ball is diamond or square. This is the geometric proof of dual norm duality: (ℓ₁)* = ℓ_∞ and (ℓ_∞)* = ℓ₁.
